memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: abs_energy

briefdescription.para:
Calculates the sum over the square values of the timeseries /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
result
An array with the same dimensions as array, whose values (time series in dimension 0) contains the sum of the squares values in the time series.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: absolute_sum_of_changes

briefdescription.para:
Calculates the sum over the absolute value of consecutive changes in the time series. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
result
An array with the same dimensions as array, whose values (time series in dimension 0) contains absolute value of consecutive changes in the time series.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref int aggregation_function, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: aggregated_autocorrelation

briefdescription.para: Calculates the value of an aggregation function f_agg (e.g. var or mean) of the autocorrelation (Compare to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autocorrelation#Estimation), taken over different all possible lags (1 to length of x).

parameterdescription.para:
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
aggregation_function
Function to be used in the aggregation. It receives an integer which indicates the function to be applied: { 0 : mean, 1 : median 2 : min, 3 : max, 4 : stdev, 5 : var, default : mean }
result
An array whose values contains the aggregated correaltion for each time series.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref long chunkSize, [In] ref int aggregation_function, [Out] out IntPtr slope, [Out] out IntPtr intercept, [Out] out IntPtr rvalue, [Out] out IntPtr pvalue, [Out] out IntPtr stderrest)
memberdef.name: aggregated_linear_trend

briefdescription.para: Calculates a linear least-squares regression for values of the time series that were aggregated over chunks versus the sequence from 0 up to the number of chunks minus one.

parameterdescription.para: The time series to calculate the features of
The chunk size used to aggregate the data.
Function to be used in the aggregation. It receives an integer which indicates the function to be applied: { 0 : mean, 1 : median 2 : min, 3 : max, 4 : stdev, default : mean }
Two-sided p-value for a hypothesis test whose null hypothesis is that the slope is zero, using Wald Test with t-distribution of the test statistic.
Standard error of the estimated gradient.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref int m, [In] ref float r, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: approximate_entropy

briefdescription.para:
Calculates a vectorized Approximate entropy algorithm. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Approximate_entropy For short time-series this method is highly dependent on the parameters, but should be stable for N > 2000, see: Yentes et al. (2012) - The Appropriate Use of Approximate Entropy and Sample Entropy with Short Data Sets Other shortcomings and alternatives discussed in: Richman & Moorman (2000) - Physiological time-series analysis using approximate entropy and sample entropy. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
m
Length of compared run of data.
r
Filtering level, must be positive.
result
The vectorized approximate entropy for all the input time series in array.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr xss, [In] ref IntPtr yss, [In] ref bool unbiased, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: cross_covariance

briefdescription.para:
Calculates the cross-covariance of the given time series. /summary>
xss
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
yss
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
unbiased
Determines whether it divides by n - lag (if true) or n (if false).
result
The cross-covariance value for the given time series.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref bool unbiased, [Out] out IntPtr result)

briefdescription.para:
Calculates the auto-covariance the given time series. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
unbiased
Determines whether it divides by n - lag (if true) or n (if false).
result
The auto-covariance value for the given time series.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr xss, [In] ref IntPtr yss, [In] ref bool unbiased, [Out] out IntPtr result)

xss
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
yss
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
unbiased
Determines whether it divides by n - lag (if true) or n (if false).
result

memberdef.name: cid_ce

Calculates an estimate for the time series complexity defined by Batista, Gustavo EAPA, et al (2014). (A more complex time series has more peaks, valleys, etc.). /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.

parameterdescription.para:
Controls whether the time series should be z-normalized or not.
result
The complexity value for the given time series.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref IntPtr width, [In] ref int coeff, [In] ref int w, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: cwt_coefficients

briefdescription.para: Calculates a Continuous wavelet transform for the Ricker wavelet, also known as the "Mexican hat wavelet" which is defined by:

detaileddescription.para: where :math:a is the width parameter of the wavelet function.

This feature calculator takes three different parameter: widths, coeff and w. The feature calculator takes all the different widths arrays and then calculates the cwt one time for each different width array. Then the values for the different coefficient for coeff and width w are returned. (For each dic in param one feature is returned). /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
width
Array that contains all different widths.
coeff
Coefficient of interest.
w
Width of interest.
result
Result of calculated coefficients.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref long num_segments, [In] ref long segment_focus, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: energy_ratio_by_chunks

briefdescription.para:
Calculates the sum of squares of chunk i out of N chunks expressed as a ratio. with the sum of squares over the whole series. segmentFocus should be lower than the number of segments /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
num_segments
The number of segments to divide the series into.
segment_focus
The segment number (starting at zero) to return a feature on.
result
The energy ratio by chunk of the time series.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: fft_aggregated

Calculates the spectral centroid(mean), variance, skew, and kurtosis of the absolute fourier transform spectrum. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
result
The spectral centroid (mean), variance, skew, and kurtosis of the absolute fourier transform spectrum.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref long coefficient, [Out] out IntPtr real, [Out] out IntPtr imag, [Out] out IntPtr absolute, [Out] out IntPtr angle)
memberdef.name: fft_coefficient

Calculates the fourier coefficients of the one-dimensional discrete Fourier Transform for real input by fast fourier transformation algorithm. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
coefficient
The coefficient to extract from the FFT.
real
The real part of the coefficient.
imag
The imaginary part of the cofficient.
absolute
The absolute value of the coefficient.
angle
The angle of the coefficient.

array

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref int m, [In] ref float r, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: friedrich_coefficients

briefdescription.para: Coefficients of polynomial $h(x)$, which has been fitted to the deterministic dynamics of Langevin model: \[ \dot(x)(t) = h(x(t)) + R \mathcal(N)(0,1) \] as described by [1]. For short time series this method is highly dependent on the parameters.

detaileddescription.para:
[1] Friedrich et al. (2000): Physics Letters A 271, p. 217-222 Extracting model equations from experimental data. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
m
Order of polynom to fit for estimating fixed points of dynamics.
r
Number of quantils to use for averaging.
result
The coefficients for each time series.

result

array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
result

(2000): Physics Letters A 271, p. 217-222 ///Extracting model equations from experimental data. /summary>

memberdef.name: number_crossing_m

briefdescription.para:
Calculates the number of m-crossings. A m-crossing is defined as two sequential values where the first value is lower than m and the next is greater, or viceversa. If you set m to zero, you will get the number of zero crossings. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
m
The m value.
result
The number of m-crossings of each time series within array.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref int max_w, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: number_cwt_peaks

briefdescription.para:
This feature calculator searches for different peaks. To do so, the time series is smoothed by a ricker wavelet and for widths ranging from 1 to max_w. This feature calculator returns the number of peaks that occur at enough width scales and with sufficiently high Signal-to-Noise-Ratio (SNR). /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
max_w
The maximum width to consider.
result
The number of peaks for each time series.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref int n, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: number_peaks

briefdescription.para:
Calculates the number of peaks of at least support $n$ in the time series $array$. A peak of support $n$ is defined as a subsequence of $array$ where a value occurs, which is bigger than its $n$ neighbours to the left and to the right. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
n
The support of the peak.
result
The number of peaks of at least support $n$.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref IntPtr lags, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: partial_autocorrelation

briefdescription.para: Calculates the value of the partial autocorrelation function at the given lag. The lag $k$ partial autocorrelation of a time series $\lbrace x_t, t = 1 \ldots T \rbrace$ equals the partial correlation of $x_t$ and $x_{t-k}$, adjusted for the intermediate variables $\lbrace x_{t-1}, \ldots, x_{t-k+1} \rbrace$ ([1]). Following [2], it can be defined as:

detaileddescription.para: \[ \alpha_k = \frac{ Cov(x_t, x_{t-k} | x_{t-1}, \ldots, x_{t-k+1})} {\sqrt{ Var(x_t | x_{t-1}, \ldots, x_{t-k+1}) Var(x_{t-k} | x_{t-1}, \ldots, x_{t-k+1} )}} \] with (a) $x_t = f(x_{t-1}, \ldots, x_{t-k+1})$ and (b) $ x_{t-k} = f(x_{t-1}, \ldots, x_{t-k+1})$ being AR(k-1) models that can be fitted by OLS. Be aware that in (a), the regression is done on past values to predict $ x_t $ whereas in (b), future values are used to calculate the past value $x_{t-k}$. It is said in [1] that "for an AR(p), the partial autocorrelations \form#21 will be nonzero for \form#22 and zero for \form#23." With this property, it is used to determine the lag of an AR-Process.

[1] Box, G. E., Jenkins, G. M., Reinsel, G. C., & Ljung, G. M. (2015). Time series analysis: forecasting and control. John Wiley & Sons. [2] https://onlinecourses.science.psu.edu/stat510/node/62 /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
lags
Indicates the lags to be calculated.
result
Returns partial autocorrelation for each time series for the given lag.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref bool is_sorted, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: percentage_of_reoccurring_datapoints_to_all_datapoints

briefdescription.para:
Calculates the percentage of unique values, that are present in the time series more than once. \[ len(different values occurring more than once) / len(different values) \] This means the percentage is normalized to the number of unique values, in contrast to the percentageOfReoccurringValuesToAllValues. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
is_sorted
Indicates if the input time series is sorted or not. Defaults to false.
result
Returns the percentage of unique values, that are present in the time series more than once.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref bool is_sorted, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: percentage_of_reoccurring_values_to_all_values

briefdescription.para:
Calculates the percentage of unique values, that are present in the time series more than once. \[ \frac{\textit{number of data points occurring more than once}}{\textit{number of all data points})} \] This means the percentage is normalized to the number of unique values, in contrast to the percentageOfReoccurringDatapointsToAllDatapoints. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
is_sorted
Indicates if the input time series is sorted or not. Defaults to false.
result
Returns the percentage of unique values, that are present in the time series more than once.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref IntPtr q, [In] ref float precision, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: quantile

briefdescription.para:
Returns values at the given quantile. /summary>
array

q
Percentile(s) at which to extract score(s). One or many.
precision
Number of decimals expected.
result
Values at the given quantile.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref float min, [In] ref float max, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: range_count

briefdescription.para:
Counts observed values within the interval [min, max). /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
min
Value that sets the lower limit.
max
Value that sets the upper limit.
result
Values at the given range.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref float r, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: ratio_beyond_r_sigma

briefdescription.para:
Calculates the ratio of values that are more than $r///std(x)$ (so $r$ sigma) away from the mean of $x$. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
r
Number of times that the values should be away from.
result
The ratio of values that are more than $r///std(x)$ (so $r$ sigma) away from the mean of $x$.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: ratio_value_number_to_time_series_length

briefdescription.para: Calculates a factor which is 1 if all values in the time series occur only once, and below one if this is not the case. In principle, it just returns:

detaileddescription.para:
\[ \frac{\textit{number\_unique\_values}}{\textit{number\_values}} \] /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
result
The ratio of unique values with respect to the total number of values.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: sample_entropy

briefdescription.para:
Calculates a vectorized sample entropy algorithm. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sample_entropy https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10843903?dopt=Abstract For short time-series this method is highly dependent on the parameters, but should be stable for N > 2000, see: Yentes et al. (2012) - The Appropriate Use of Approximate Entropy and Sample Entropy with Short Data Sets Other shortcomings and alternatives discussed in: Richman & Moorman (2000) - Physiological time-series analysis using approximate entropy and sample entropy. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
result
An array with the same dimensions as array, whose values (time series in dimension 0) contains the vectorized sample entropy for all the input time series in array.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: skewness

briefdescription.para:
Calculates the sample skewness of array (calculated with the adjusted Fisher-Pearson standardized moment coefficient G1). /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
result
Array containing the skewness of each time series in array.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref int coeff, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: spkt_welch_density

briefdescription.para: Estimates the cross power spectral density of the time series array at different frequencies. To do so, the time series is first shifted from the time domain to the frequency domain.

detaileddescription.para:
Welch's method computes an estimate of the power spectral density by dividing the data into overlapping segments, computing a modified periodogram for each segment and averaging the periodograms. [1] P. Welch, "The use of the fast Fourier transform for the estimation of power spectra: A method based on time averaging over short, modified periodograms", IEEE Trans. Audio Electroacoust. vol. 15, pp. 70-73, 1967. [2] M.S. Bartlett, "Periodogram Analysis and Continuous Spectra", Biometrika, vol. 37, pp. 1-16, 1950. [3] Rabiner, Lawrence R., and B. Gold. "Theory and Application of Digital Signal Processing" Prentice-Hall, pp. 414-419, 1975. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
coeff
The coefficient to be returned.
result
Array containing the power spectrum of the different frequencies for each time series in array.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: standard_deviation

briefdescription.para:
Calculates the standard deviation of each time series within array. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
result
The standard deviation of each time series within array.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref bool is_sorted, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: sum_of_reoccurring_datapoints

briefdescription.para:
Calculates the sum of all data points, that are present in the time series more than once. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
is_sorted
Indicates if the input time series is sorted or not. Defaults to false.
result
Returns the sum of all data points, that are present in the time series more than once.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref bool is_sorted, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: sum_of_reoccurring_values

briefdescription.para:
Calculates the sum of all values, that are present in the time series more than once. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
is_sorted
Indicates if the input time series is sorted or not. Defaults to false.
result
Returns the sum of all values, that are present in the time series more than once.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: sum_values

briefdescription.para:
Calculates the sum over the time series array. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
result
An array containing the sum of values in each time series.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref float r, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: symmetry_looking

briefdescription.para:
Calculates if the distribution of array ///looks symmetric///. This is the case if \[ | mean(array)-median(array)| \lt r * (max(array)-min(array)) \] /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
r
The percentage of the range to compare with.
result
An array denoting if the input time series look symmetric.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref int lag, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: time_reversal_asymmetry_statistic

briefdescription.para: This function calculates the value of: \[ \frac{1}{n-2lag} \sum_{i=0}^{n-2lag} x_{i + 2 \cdot lag}^2 \cdot x_{i + lag} - x_{i + lag} \cdot x_{i}^2 \] which is \[ \mathbb{E}[L^2(X)^2 \cdot L(X) - L(X) \cdot X^2] \] where $ \mathbb{E} $ is the mean and $ L $ is the lag operator. It was proposed in [1] as a promising feature to extract from time series.

detaileddescription.para:
[1] Fulcher, B.D., Jones, N.S. (2014). Highly comparative feature-based time-series classification. Knowledge and Data Engineering, IEEE Transactions on 26, 30263037. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
lag
The lag to be computed.
result
An array containing the time reversal asymetry statistic value in each time series.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [In] ref float v, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: value_count

briefdescription.para:
Counts occurrences of value in the time series array. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
v
The value to be counted.
result
An array containing the count of the given value in each time series.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: variance

briefdescription.para:
Computes the variance for the time series array. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
result
An array containing the variance in each time series.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr array, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: variance_larger_than_standard_deviation

briefdescription.para:
Calculates if the variance of array is greater than the standard deviation. In other words, if the variance of array is larger than 1. /summary>
array
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series (all the same) and dimension one indicates the number of time series.
result
An array denoting if the variance of array is greater than the standard deviation.
Khiva Features class containing a number of features that can be extracted from time series. All the methods operate with instances of the ARRAY class as input and output.
